Hello Martin,

Thanks much for your inputs on my query. have skimmed throug=
h the junit
cookbook and the junit faq's posted by this mailing list. howev=
er, not able
to find out how should i begin with. I don't have to do unit t=
esting. i am
an QA engineer. my task is to automate my testing using junit =
.

all I have is all the urls where these API are available and the query
p=
arameters that they take before they send response. The response can be in
=
xml or json or php format. in fact In my http call to those, i have to
sugg=
est in which format response should be...(its one of the query string
param=
eter in my request)

once I get the response, parse them take some of the p=
arameters (like say if
I call the login API, i will get a session cookie wh=
ich i have to send on
consequent request)and build another request and call=
 different API.

Thanks again !

please help.

Cheers, S



On Mon, Apr 7, =
2008 at 4:00 PM, B=F6hm, Martin <martin.boehm@...>
wrote:

> =
  Hi,
>
> first you should know, that you have to dig in more advanced
> ju=
nit topics to cope with your task.
>
> For myself I read http://junit.sourc=
eforge.net/ and the
> JUnit-Cookbook as beginner. It's a simple starting po=
int to
> get into unittesting. Especially in your case I would suggest
> yo=
u to get more acquainted with junit.
>
> A more advanced book that gives a =
very deep understanding
> of unit tests I found in "xUnit Test Patterns"
> =
(Gerard Meszaros). That should give you the real taste of
> junit without s=
uffering the common junit beginner pitfalls.
>
> In the second step you sho=
uld be able to decide if you
> use pure junit to take your task or to use a=
 framework
> additional, that may simplify some testing tasks in your
> env=
ironment, for example to test http-communication.
>
> best regards
> Martin=
